704319f-a.title: Brooklyn: Flatbush Avenue - Kings Highway
704319f-a.text:
Flatbush Ave., west side, between Kings Hiighway and Flatlands Ave..
now (1936), approximately 78-84 Flatbush Ave.  This was knonn as the Peter
Lott house, after Peter Lott who settled in Flatbush about 1650. His
descendants, Johannes E. and Abraham Lott, purchased it from Aert Willenoss,
early in the 18th century. It has been razed.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE PEPRODUCED.
704319f-a.folder: Flatbush Avenue & Kings Highway, Brooklyn, NY

705241f-c.title: Brooklyn: Kings Highway - Flatbush Avenue
705241f-c.text:
(1)
Kings Highway, (Kouwenhoven Lane), south side, east from Flatbush
Ave., to East 40th Street, showing part of the John J. Ryder (formerly
the J. C. Ryder) house on the right, and the J. 3. Hendrickson House
in the extreme background. All these houses except the Hendrickson
house, were demolished in May 1925.
March 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE RERR ODUCED.
(2)
The same, from a point further east from Flatbush Ave., showing
the Hendfickson House (in the background), and the Garretson House at
the right.
March 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(3)
The same, showing the Garretson House at the right, known once as  61
Kouwenhoven Lne. This house was occupied by the Garretson family from
1857 to 1873. At the left is seen the Hendrickson House at the N.E.
corner of Kings Highway and East 40th Street.
March 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
705241f-c.folder: Kings Highway & Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY

705240f-a.title: Brooklyn: Kings Highway - Flatbush Avenue
705240f-a.text:
King's Highway, north side, between Flatbush Ave., and East 40th Street.
In the background, is seen the Flatland Dutch Reform Cemetery. The old
houses are landmarks of old farms, slowly disappearing in this section.
August 7, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
705240f-a.folder: Kings Highway & Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY

704315f-b.title: Brooklyn: Flatbush Avenue - Kings Highway
704315f-b.text:
(1)
Flatbush Ave., at the N.E. corner of King's Highway, showing
''Hendrickson's corner''. This building was for 66 years, kept by the
Hendrickson's as a general store and post office. The upper part was
uused as a meeting room, town hall and court room. J. B. Hendrickson was
the original owner and thereafter his son Elias continued the business.
TThe building was remodeled in 1925.
1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, a closer view.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

Gilfeather. Now (1936) it is no longer standing.

704317f-b.title: Brooklyn: Flatbush Avenue - Kings Highway
704317f-b.text:
(1
Flatbush Ave., west side, between King's Highway and Flatlands
Ave., showing the Peter Lott farmhouse, erected about 1857, and destroy-
ed by fire in December 1925, now the site of the Marine Theatre. This
house was occupied by Peter Lott from 1857 to 1860, by lrs Keenan in 1875
and by Mrs. Ferris J. Bergen in 1922.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
2)
The same, from another angle.
April 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
3)
The same, from another angle.
AUust 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

705237f-a.title: Brooklyn: Kings Highway - Flatbush Avenue
705237f-a.text:
Kings Highway, at the N.W. corner of Flatbush Ave. It is said that
the land on which this house stands, was sold by Elbert Elbertsen in 1676 to
Peter Wyckoff. Iw 1797 Simon Voorhies cemwe into possession of it, and used
it as a tavern. John B. Durges owned it until 1820, used it as a tavern for
about 20 years. Abraham Torhune became the next owner and his estate sold
it in 1843 to John Bergen who built a 2-story extension on the west side, the
first floor becoming a ballroom and the second floor sleeping quarters. In
1855 John Logue became the owner. William R. Mc Neil became the owner in
1860 and in 1874 John Van Wyck bought the property and lived in it until 1882.
Letween 1882 and 1895 the place became an ice cream parlor and saloon, and
from 1895 to 1902 the Amersfort Hotel was kept here. In 1902 the property
reverted to the heirs of John Van Wyck and was demolished in 1923.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE PEPRODUCED.
705237f-a.folder: Kings Highway & Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
